ch.epfl.alpano

Interface Math2


  • public interface Math2
    This interface is an extension of Math providing extra mathematical functions.
    Author:
    Martin Cibils (261746), Jeremy Mion (261178)

      • floorMod

        static double floorMod(double x,
                       double y)
        Calculates the floored mod of the parameter x using the following formula.

        x mod_floored y = x-y*(x dif_floored y)

        Parameters:
        x - argument that will be used as the number that we want to take the floor mod of
        y - that will be used to divide by
        Returns:
        the floored mod. x mod_floor y

        Returns:

      • lerp

        static double lerp(double y0,
                   double y1,
                   double x)
        Calculates the value of x using linear interpolation based on 2 known points.
        Parameters:
        y0 - Value of the function in x = 0.
        y1 - Value of the function in x = 1.
        x - The point that needs to be interpolated.
        Returns:
        The value of the linear approximation of the function in x.

      • bilerp

        static double bilerp(double z00,
                     double z10,
                     double z01,
                     double z11,
                     double x,
                     double y)
        Calculates the value of a bilinear interpolation.

        This allows for interpolation in 3D knowing only 4 points. This method will calculate the value of z given 4 points in 3D. To specify where the z value that is being looked is the x and y variables represent it's location.

        Parameters:
        z00 - Is the value of z when x = 0 and y = 0
        z10 - Is the value of z when x = 1 and y = 0
        z01 - Is the value of z when x = 0 and y = 1
        z11 - Is the value of z when x = 1 and y = 1
        x - The x coordinate of the z value that is being interpolated.
        y - The y coordinate of the z value that is being interpolated.
        Returns:
        The value in the z axis of the interpolation of the point located at the location (x,y).

      • firstIntervalContainingRoot

        static double firstIntervalContainingRoot(java.util.function.DoubleUnaryOperator f,
                                          double minX,
                                          double maxX,
                                          double dX)
        Finds the root of of the function f.

        The search starts at bornMin and will progress until reaching bornMax. If no root is found within the interval Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY will be returned.

        This method will look for a change of sign to detect a root and will return the lower bound of the interval dx where the change of sign was detected.

        Parameters:
        f - The function that we are looking for the roots of.
        minX - The lower bound of where the search will begin to look for roots.
        maxX - The upper bound of where the search will stop looking for roots.
        dX - The size of the interval that the search algorithm will use when looking for the roots
        Returns:
        The lower of the interval of size dx that contains the root. If no root found Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY will re returned

      • improveRoot

        static double improveRoot(java.util.function.DoubleUnaryOperator f,
                          double x1,
                          double x2,
                          double epsilon)
        Calculates the zeros (roots) of a function f by using the dicotomie method.

        This method will split the interval between x1 and x2 into 2 until the distance between the 2 is smaller or equal to epsilon. The method will also stop it search if the exact value of the root is found.

        Parameters:
        f - The function that is being analyzed to find it's roots.
        x1 - The lower bound of where the search begins.
        x2 - The upper bound of where the search ends.
        epsilon - The distance that x1 and x2 can be apart so that the algorithm concludes it has successfully found the answer.
        Returns:
        The lower bound of the interval smaller than or equal to epsilon.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if no root is contained between x1 and x2.
